item.content:encoded:
I’m a PhD candidate in Law at University College London. My research draws from ecology and evolutionary economics to ask how competition law can understand market competition as a process. I run the Law and Political Economy Group at UCL Laws.

I hold a master’s degree in Politics and Technology from the Technical University Munich and a bachelor’s degree in Computer Science from The University of Manchester. I previously worked for six years as a software engineer at Google, mostly in the security and privacy space.

I’m interested in topics which ultimately impact human flourishing. In particular, virtue ethics and how social technologies can be a force for good in an age of metacrisis (surpassed planetary boundaries, increasing inequality, geopolitical strife, existential risk production, etc).

item.title: Some Things I Believe
item.author: todd@todddavi.es (Todd Davies)
item.description: Here is some stuff I believe, in no particular order. item.content:encoded:
Here is some stuff I believe, in no particular order.

  • Work on stuff you like
    • Doing great work requires motivation
    • It’s easier to be motivated when you like something
    • Things become more enjoyable when you get good at them
  • We should aim for great things
    • We only get one life
    • It’s better to use it on significant things, rather than to “muddle through”
    • You can still enjoy something, even if you ultimately fail
    • Success is mostly about perspiration and luck. Luck favours the prepared mind.
  • Align yourself with the public interest
    • Your own interest is important
    • But it has diminishing returns
    • You can align your private interest with the public interest
    • Working in the public interest has a higher ceiling
    • Don’t underestimate your capacity to change the world
  • We should think reflexively
    • It’s possible to critically assess your own thought patterns
    • This lets you improve how you think
    • You can become a better person by doing this
  • Think in systems
    • Problems often don’t have a direct cause
    • They have several or many interlocking causes
    • Challenges and responses > problems and solutions
    • Look to think synergistically across domains when responding to challenges
  • Speed is important
    • You learn via receiving feedback from your actions
    • The quicker you execute, the more feedback you’ll generate
  • Self discipline is delayed gratification
    • Delaying gratification is a form of self love
  • Avoid competition with others
    • Competition is great for honing a specific task
    • But the world is big and weird
    • There are many tasks we can do and roles we can play
    • Pick a unique bundle of skills
    • Excel at providing those skills to the world
  • Compound returns isn’t just for money
    • Compound returns works on relationships, skills, knowledge, etc
    • E.g. The more things we know, the easier it is to learn more things
    • Continually invest in learning, people, etc
    • Most investments will make modest returns, some will give huge ones
  • We should focus on what we can control
    • The only thing we can truly control is our thoughts and actions
    • We can’t even control our bodies (e.g. we get sick)
    • Focus on what you can control, avoid worrying about what you can’t
  • Don’t put off the good life
    • Putting things off is a trap; we might never get to them
    • You can be content in a surprising number of circumstances
    • You get to decide what the good life looks like
  • Wisdom only correlates with age
    • Wisdom comes from distilling knowledge out of experience
    • Experience correlates with age
    • People are better/worse at extracting knowledge from their experiences
    • It is possible to exist but not really live
